title: Minority Rule: Adventures in the Culture War
author: Ash Sarkar

title: The Man Who Died Twice (Thursday Murder Club, #2)
author: Richard Osman

title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
author: Philip K. Dick

title: Born to be Mild: Adventures for the Anxious
author: Rob Temple

title: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd (Hercule Poirot, #4)
author: Agatha Christie
summary: Surprisingly modern for a book written nearly 100 years ago. A solid murder mystery.

title: Shades of Grey (Shades of Grey, #1)
author: Jasper Fforde
summary: Felt like a long read and felt a little like it was trying to be Red Dwarf a few times, but eventually settled into an interesting and fun story.

title: The Thursday Murder Club (Thursday Murder Club, #1)
author: Richard Osman
summary: So good on all levels. Utterly polished and wonderfully likeable characters.

title: Piranesi
author: Susanna Clarke
summary: Kind of lovely. Kind of trippy.

title: Virtual Light (Bridge Trilogy, #1)
author: William Gibson
summary: Decent enough, even if I didn't really get it.

title: Seveneves
author: Neal Stephenson
summary: Way, way, way too long. Barely any story in the 860 pages, it gets some drama around 85% in and holds on for a short while.

title: Hope to Die (DI Adam Fawley, #6)
author: Cara Hunter
summary: Literal page turner. Over 400 pages and I swallowed it in days.

title: The Wasp Factory
author: Iain Banks
summary: Unique.

title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (Space Odyssey, #1)
author: Arthur C. Clarke
summary: I wanted to enjoy this, but perhaps too smart for an actual story.

title: Iron Widow (Iron Widow, #1)
author: Xiran Jay Zhao
summary: Didn't so much smash the patriarchy than slit it's throat and stand over it whilst it bled out!

title: A Psalm for the Wild-Built (Monk & Robot, #1)
author: Becky Chambers
summary: Lovely but I found the language almost too distracting.

title: Hercule Poirot's Christmas (Hercule Poirot, #20)
author: Agatha Christie
summary: I totally failed to guess the killer!

title: The Wise Man's Fear (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #2)
author: Patrick Rothfuss
summary: A wonderful journey into Rothfuss' world.

title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #1)
seriesEntry: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
author: Douglas Adams
summary: My kind of silly.

title: Home: Habitat, Range, Niche, Territory (The Murderbot Diaries, #4.5)
author: Martha Wells
summary: Very brief but a good bridging story.

title: The Whole Truth (DI Adam Fawley, #5)
author: Cara Hunter
summary: Unstoppable page turner.

title: The Call of the Wild
author: Jack London
summary: Far more brutal than I expected.

title: Broad Band: The Untold Story of the Women Who Made the Internet
seriesEntry: Broad Band: The Untold Story of the Women Who Made the Internet
author: Claire L Evans
summary: A real kind of urgency and excitement in their writing. Superb.

title: Marge and the Secret Tunnel (Marge, #4)
author: Isla Fisher
summary: The kids absolutely love the Marge in Charge series.

title: Fugitive Telemetry (The Murderbot Diaries, #6)
author: Martha Wells
summary: I'll never tire of how bored the Murderbot is!

title: The Galaxy, and the Ground Within (Wayfarers, #4)
seriesEntry: The Galaxy, and the Ground Within
author: Becky Chambers
summary: Surprisingly difficult to connect with.

title: James Acaster's Classic Scrapes
author: James Acaster
summary: Acaster also has a distinctive style if you've seen him on screen so in reading his stories, Acaster's voice really leaps from the words on the page.

title: To Be Taught, If Fortunate
author: Becky Chambers
summary: To Be Taught is another excellent story from Becky Chambers. Gently, honest, touching and inquisitive about the universe.

title: Who Am I, Again?
author: Lenny Henry
summary: Growing up with Lenny Henry as a stable diet of light comedy his early years story was enlightening.

title: Zed
author: Joanna Kavenna
summary: A good read, rather on the nose as to the BS that exists in tech

title: The Master and Margarita
author: Mikhail Bulgakov
summary: I literally have no idea what I read!

title: Last Christmas
author: Greg Wise
summary: Many, many personal stories of Christmas, perfect for Christmas time reading even if most carry the same message: family.

title: The Midnight Library
author: Matt Haig
summary: Predictable

title: A Closed and Common Orbit (Wayfarers, #2)
author: Becky Chambers
summary: Enjoyed this story - it had a lot of warmth.

title: All My Friends Are Superheroes
author: Andrew Kaufman
summary: Nice interesting take on storytelling.

title: The Stone Man
author: Luke Smitherd
summary: Couldn't get on with this book **at all**.

title: The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet (Wayfarers, #1)
seriesEntry: The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet
author: Becky Chambers

title: Stardust
author: Gaiman, Neil
summary: A well told tale of magic and adventure. And more of a starting point for its movie counterpart

title: All the Rage
author: Cara Hunter
summary: The hate crimes make this for brutal reading, but, as always, incredible engaging.

title: And Then There Were None
author: Agatha Christie
summary: My first Christie book, and it did not disappoint.

title: The Bell Jar
author: Sylvia Plath
summary: This is a hard book to read, partly for the confused start, but also the very real ending. A deep insight into clinical depression.

title: Spectrum Machine Language for the Absolute Beginner
author: William Tang

title: Network Effect (The Murderbot Diaries, #5)
author: Martha Wells
summary: Fun stuff, as always, but requires prior knowledge

title: The Cuckoo's Calling (Cormoran Strike, #1)
author: Robert Galbraith
summary: Pretty much middle of the road read.

title: Close to Home (DI Adam Fawley, #1)
author: Cara Hunter
summary: Solid reading, what I've come to expect from Hunter.

title: The Little Prince
author: Antoine de Saint-Exup√©ry
summary: Innocent and beautiful and left me wanting to take pause when looking around.

title: Speccy Nation
author: Dan Whitehead
summary: Fun writing but does end up being a game by game review.

title: The Princess Diarist
author: Carrie Fisher
summary: Good lord I miss this woman. I could read and listen to her stories all day.

title: Children of Time (Children of Time, #1)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
summary: Interesting, well written and some nice ideas, but for me, wow, a long read that seemingly never ended.

title: In the Dark (DI Adam Fawley, #2)
author: Cara Hunter
summary: Kept me guessing and an easy read.

title: Flowers for Algernon
author: Daniel Keyes
summary: Heartbreaking and thought provoking.

title: Exhalation
author: Ted Chiang
summary: Thought provoking, some interesting ideas, but a tough act to follow.

title: The Testaments (The Handmaid's Tale, #2)
author: Margaret Atwood
summary: Brutal.

title: We
author: Yevgeny Zamyatin
summary: Beautiful prose but no idea what it was about!

title: Skipping Christmas: Christmas with The Kranks
seriesEntry: Skipping Christmas: Christmas with The Kranks
author: John Grisham

title: My Name Is Leon
author: Kit de Waal
summary: Sad. Heart breaking. Beautiful.

title: The Book of M
author: Peng Shepherd
summary: Engaging from the very first pages, brilliant writing and ideas with some sci-fi without the need to explain absolutely everything. Loved it.

title: Recursion
author: Blake Crouch
summary: Decent sci-fi read, not terribly challenging, perhaps a bit overly grim towards the end, but entertaining all round.

title: Death's End (Remembrance of Earth‚Äôs Past, #3)
author: Cixin Liu
summary: If this were a technical rating, the book would get 5 stars. For me however, the book felt like a bit of a slog. It took me 2 months to read it and the story line, good gosh, feels like it is stretched across time.

title: The Afterlife of Walter Augustus
author: Hannah M. Lynn
summary: A bit obvious, uneventful and a miss for me.

title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Harry Potter, #4)
seriesEntry: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: Unexpected scary bits!

title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
seriesEntry: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
author: Winifred Watson
summary: All throughout reading this book, I found myself smiling.

title: The Dark Forest (Remembrance of Earth‚Äôs Past, #2)
author: Cixin Liu
summary: A tough/hard science start, but gets picks up and good gosh, the ideas in this book are‚Ä¶wow, expansive!

title: The Three-Body Problem (Remembrance of Earth‚Äôs Past, #1)
author: Cixin Liu
summary: My first \"hard science\" read, but had me immediately inspired to learn more about physics.

title: I Am Legend
author: Richard Matheson
summary: I loved it; gripping, heart warming, shameful, despairing, brilliant and quite beautiful.

title: No Way Out (DI Adam Fawley, #3)
author: Cara Hunter
summary: Well paced, well written and engaging crime thriller. Not my typical cup of tea, but really enjoyed it.

title: Meeting Mungo Thunk
author: Keith A. Pearson
summary: There's a clever story in here, with some decent humour but for me, personally, the undertone of sexism and 1980s machismo was a turn off.

title: The Passengers
author: John Marrs
summary: Certainly a page turner and an easy read. Interesting concepts on near-future issues, but I was left feeling a bit‚Ä¶unchallenged.

title: The Sudden Appearance of Hope
author: Claire North
summary: Great page turner, and I loved the concept of how an individual exits whilst always forgotten in the world.

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Ray Bradbury
summary: I loved the concept behind this story, but sadly the delivered story fell fairly flat for me.

title: Lord of the Flies
author: William Golding
summary: Stressful, but solid, reading.

title: The Name of the Wind (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #1)
author: Patrick Rothfuss
summary: Absolutely superb stuff. This book was recommended separately by three different friends, and it lived up to expectations.

title: Sleep
author: Nick Littlehales
summary: In general, the concepts and ideas are pretty solid. A lot of common sense that revolves around using sunlight to help with sleep patterns. Somehow I personally experienced a similar sleeping pattern (sticking to a regular alarm, getting up quickly, getting sunlight) and it worked incredibly well for me for 2 years (until I broke the pattern).

title: Autonomous
author: Annalee Newitz
summary: Enjoyed this book. Definitely a modern look at the possibilities of the future ahead of us. I have to admin I was expecting more robots and augmentations and sci-fi, but this leant more towards a political statement in particular about free access to healthcare (which is something I care a lot about being in the UK and having the NHS).

title: All the Birds in the Sky
author: Charlie Jane Anders
summary: I wanted to love this book but I kinda fell short right at the end. However, the two protagonists: Patricia and Lawrence are beautifully written.

title: Clawthorn (Clement, #3)
author: Keith A Pearson
summary: I've read and enjoyed the previous two Clement stories. This story was fun, and a very easy read (for me to get through 400 pages in a matter of days is testament to that).

title: A Brief History of Everyone Who Ever Lived: The Stories in Our Genes
seriesEntry: A Brief History of Everyone Who Ever Lived: The Stories in Our Genes
author: Adam Rutherford
summary: Goodness me, this was a good book!

title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3)
seriesEntry: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: I read this to my son, who turned 7 just after we started. We did end up doing some epic bedtime reading sessions to complete whole chapters. And as with books I've read to him, I shall let his own words dictate this review :)

title: The Chrysalids
author: John Wyndham
summary: I did enjoy this story (the 3 stars wasn't a 5 for any negative reasons) - it's pretty well paced, and discusses some particularly interesting ideas.

title: Christmas Jars Collector's Edition
author: Jason F. Wright
summary: A sweet tale of kindness. I asked for recommendations for Christmas‚Äìfeelings books, and this is one that came up, and it does indeed do a good job of getting those feel‚Äìgood vibes going.

title: The Truth Pixie (Christmas, #3.5)
author: Matt Haig
summary: Good to read aloud to the kids (took about 15-20 minutes), and a beautiful message in the story, whereby the adult reading...me...might have caught a frog in their throat!

title: The Gift of the Magi
author: O. Henry
summary: I didn't quite expect the book (read on my Kindle) to be *quite* that short.

title: Exit Strategy (The Murderbot Diaries, #4)
author: Martha Wells
summary: I read the first installment of the Murderbot a few months back (as an Amazon single), but after reading it, I decided I was going to pony up the ¬£8 for the following 3 books - although probably the most I've spent on a single book, let alone 3 books - absolutely totally worth it. I **loved** this series.

title: Rogue Protocol (The Murderbot Diaries, #3)
author: Martha Wells
summary: As usual from the MurderBot series: excellent, fresh and entertaining.

title: Saga, Volume 9
author: Brian K. Vaughan
summary: Loved it. As always. Heart wrenching too.

title: Artificial Condition (The Murderbot Diaries, #2)
author: Martha Wells
summary: Uh! I love this character! This is the 2nd book in the murderbot books and the main character, who I realise now doesn't have a name (nor gender as it's a bot) is so fun to read.

title: The End Specialist
author: Drew Magary
summary: The two stars are for: fairly decent writing, it wasn't a rabib page turner, but it was relatively easy going for the most part.

title: Tin Man
author: Sarah Winman
summary: Really quite beautiful. I found myself drawing out my reading time for this book, and almost wanting to find a tree to sit under and slowly soak up this story.

title: The Brighton Mermaid
author: Dorothy Koomson
summary: Really enjoyed this thriller. An easy read and natural page turner (with nice short chapters). I was also drawn to this book because I know Brighton (UK) very very well, and I love reading stories located in places that are familiar to me.

title: War with the Newts
author: Karel ƒåapek
summary: Quite brilliant.

title: Beetle Boy
author: M.G. Leonard
summary: I read this aloud to my son at bedtime (6 turning 7 in a month). It took a chunk of time, and making the voices distinct was fun and tricky!

title: Sex and Drugs and Sausage Rolls
author: Robert Rankin
summary: Fun stuff. I didn't realise this was the sixth novel of a series, but it really didn't matter - and almost added more depth since the characters had a lot more backstory.

title: Dogs of War
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
summary: Wow. I loved this book. I'm not entirely sure how I found it - I suspect Amazon randomly recommended it to me, and it was definitely a random purchase - but so glad I did.

title: Past Mortem
author: Ben Elton
summary: My hospital read! I spent a day and night in hospital for tonsillitis, and managed to read through this book (though there's not a whole lot to do in hospital!).

title: Neuromancer
author: William Gibson
summary: Unsure. I have to admit that reading this book I often felt a little lost as to what was happening and why, but just carried on to enjoy the ride.

title: The Obesity Code
author: Jason Fung
summary: I read this book based on a recommendation regarding eating fats. On the title alone, I probably would have ignored this book, but the contents is absolutely superb.

title: Good Omens
author: Terry Pratchett
summary: Such good fun. I think my favourite character was actually Dog. I loved the inner monologue that went with the Hell Hound!

title: The Dead Fathers Club
author: Matt Haig
summary: The story of an 11 year old boy after his father dies. The story uses a unique story telling device where it's told from the boys mind (or imagined diary), but the result is a stream of consciousness, littered with rule-breaking authoring techniques.

title: All Systems Red (The Murderbot Diaries, #1)
author: Martha Wells
summary: Love it. Witty, humourous, original and fresh.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
summary: Oh wow. Where do I begin with my review? I'm always amazed at how current a book written in 1931 can be so current and readable nearly a century later in 2018.

title: Postcards From the Edge (Suzanne Vale, #1)
author: Carrie Fisher
summary: I've now read two Carrie Fisher books and I've loved them both. She is‚Ä¶was such a superb author chock full of quotable lines.

title: Snow Crash
author: Neal Stephenson
summary: (warning: not really a review, more of a thing to remind me of the book)

title: Jessica Jones, Vol. 2: The Secrets of Maria Hill
author: Brian Michael Bendis
summary: Always great stuff from Bendis and Gaydos.

title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2)
seriesEntry: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: Read aloud to the 6 year old. A little scary for him at times, and frankly I'm amazed that he can follow the story whilst I read and he (sometimes) plays with Lego!

author: George Orwell
summary: A future in my past written in a distant past. What an amazing book. Orwell's writing has lasted near perfectly (i.e. modern and in context) some 70 years later (which frankly blows my mind).

title: Stories of Your Life and Others
seriesEntry: Stories of Your Life and Others
author: Ted Chiang
summary: I absolutely loved this collection of stories. Inspiring, beautiful, not-so-sci-fi that it was disconnected from our world.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
summary: Wow this book was a slow read given that it was only 198 pages. It took me 4 weeks, which, isn't a huge amount of time, but the first 80% of the book felt like an age that just wouldn't end.

title: Adrian Mole: The Prostrate Years (Adrian Mole, #8)
author: Sue Townsend
summary: I had a hard time reading this book, took me a long time as I found Mole and the surrounding characters extremely‚Ä¶sad or pathetic or selfish. It continued on like this until about 80% where I started to enjoy the book a little more and the characters finally start to bloom and become more complex, and endearing.

title: Silent Victim
author: Caroline Mitchell
summary: Proper page turner thriller that seemed to get faster and more intense as the book worked it's way to its ending.

title: Who Sent Clement? (Clement #1)
author: Keith A Pearson
summary: Really enjoyed it, and after reading Pearson's '86 fix and the sequel, I'm pretty certain I'll continue to read his books.

title: The Night Masquerade (Binti #3)
author: Nnedi Okorafor
summary: Beautiful. Inspiring. Amazing. I loved this third installment of Binti's adventure. What an amazing world and collection of characters Nnedi Okorafor has made.

title: The Lives of Tao
author: Wesley Chu
summary: The story was interesting enough, but I ended up getting frustrated with both the author's portrayal of women throughout the book (always using physical traits to describe them, like beautiful, or soft skin), and then there's an entire chapter dedicated to sexist undertones of "how women are past their prime by 30s".

title: The Unbeatable Squirrel Girl, Vol. 1: Squirrel Power
author: Ryan North
summary: Nice alternative to the super heroes I've read in the past. A very strong young woman (that I'd want to share with my kids), and surprisingly doesn't kick butts as often as she alludes to, but uses sensible discussion and compassion to bypass her foes.

title: Wishful Drinking: Carrie Fisher
author: Carrie Fisher
summary: Very easy and quick read (for me). The writing is extremely conversational (which makes for a nice change).

title: The Power
author: Naomi Alderman
summary: Loved this book. For me, it puts a magnifying glass on the grotesque behaviours that men have and still do, inflict on women, simply because of gender, this warped idea that one is stronger than the other. As a man this book is a huge insight into the reality of the power struggle, along with being a great page turner and great thriller.

title: Saga, Volume 8
author: Brian K. Vaughan
summary: Another superb Saga volume. The artwork is so incredible, subtle and respectful - as in the writing.

title: A Gentleman in Moscow
author: Amor Towles
summary: A beautiful tale, and the detail of the characters, their surroundings and the history throughout the book made me often wonder if it was actually a biography!

title: A Christmas Carol
author: Charles Dickens
summary: I've known the story for many, many years, and had voices for the characters in my head, but had never read it. Really good, classic stuff. Dickens certainly knew how to string out a sentence too! They'd often start at the end of one page, continue through the next, and finish on the third!

title: Everyone's a Aliebn When Ur a Aliebn Too
seriesEntry: Everyone's a Aliebn When Ur a Aliebn Too
author: Jomny Sun

title: How Not To Be a Boy
seriesEntry: How Not To Be a Boy
author: Robert Webb
summary: Not what I had hoped.

title: Beyond Broadhall (The '86 Fix #2)
author: Keith A Pearson
summary: Loved it. I happened to read this directly after the '86 Fix, and although it didn't have the same "retro" feel of the first book, it was superb all the same.

title: The Ocean at the End of the Lane
seriesEntry: The Ocean at the End of the Lane
author: Neil Gaiman

title: The First Fifteen Lives of Harry August
seriesEntry: The First Fifteen Lives of Harry August
author: Claire North

title: The Girl With All the Gifts
author: M.R. Carey
summary: I loved this book. I'm not a fan of the apocalyptic stories, but this is so well told both from the storyline, but also the _way_ the story was written and each chapter is given from the perspective of the character (whilst still being 3rd person)‚Äîthat I couldn't put the book down. Love it.

title: The Girl Who Saved the King of Sweden
seriesEntry: The Girl Who Saved the King of Sweden
author: Jonas Jonasson

title: The Humans
author: Matt Haig
summary: My first read-twice book. A love letter to humanity.

title: The Five People You Meet in Heaven
seriesEntry: The Five People You Meet in Heaven
author: Mitch Albom

title: A Boy Made of Blocks
author: Keith Stuart
summary: I loved this story. It helps that I'm a dad with a son who has some similarities to the characters, but I found this story so warm and loving. I also found myself dragging the ending out just so that I could continue to have these characters in my life a little longer.

title: The Song From Somewhere Else
author: A.F. Harrold
summary: Beautiful story (and printed paper was so nice).

title: A Boy Called Christmas
author: Matt Haig
summary: Always lovely. Though kinda ends about 25% short of the actual ending, then it's a little dragged out.
